tier.item: The term `ethnosyntax' was coined by Wierzbicka (1979) to mean what Enfield calls ethnosyntax in its narrow sense.
Ethnosyntax in its broad sense concerns culturally mediated uses or interpretations of pieces of grammar.
My view of grammaticisation is broader than the current mainstream position. I understand, with Himmelmann (1997: 33),
that it is constructions that are grammaticised. Much mainstream grammaticisation theory deals with the semantic bleach-
ing and phonological erosion of words and morphemes, but these processes take place in the context of constructional
grammaticisation. They are common, but not necessary, outcomes.
Enfield (2002b: 3) appears to claim that Russan constructions described by Wierzbicka (1992: 395­441) directly encode
cultural values. Wierzbicka herself does not claim this here, and much of what she presents consists of a set of argument-
structure constructions associated with particular verbs, i.e. particular lexical items. It is the combination of the verb and
the argument-structure construction that carries meaning, not the construction alone (Goldberg 1995, Croft 2003a).
`I sang in the only way I know' (Hill 1969: 348, 350)

Ethnosyntax in its broad sense concerns culturally mediated uses or interpretations of pieces of grammar.
My view of grammaticisation is broader than the current mainstream position. I understand, with Himmelmann (1997: 33),
that it is constructions that are grammaticised. Much mainstream grammaticisation theory deals with the semantic bleach-
ing and phonological erosion of words and morphemes, but these processes take place in the context of constructional
grammaticisation. They are common, but not necessary, outcomes.
Enfield (2002b: 3) appears to claim that Russan constructions described by Wierzbicka (1992: 395­441) directly encode
cultural values. Wierzbicka herself does not claim this here, and much of what she presents consists of a set of argument-
structure constructions associated with particular verbs, i.e. particular lexical items. It is the combination of the verb and
the argument-structure construction that carries meaning, not the construction alone (Goldberg 1995, Croft 2003a).
